moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3
comment:
Good move! This deprives the
black B on c8 and N on f6 of a possible post on g4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6
comment:
Black's last move is
rather dubious. In most King pawn openings, Piece play is everthing. Much more
logical is 7. ... cxd4 8. Nxd4 Re8, with a slightly cramped but solid position
for black. Notice that White can't play 9. Bg5? Nxe4! as this would win a pawn
for black.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6
comment:
There is no need for this move. Black should still play
the plan mentioned on move 7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7
comment:
? Definitely
a mistake. Black should of course continue development with ...Nbd7 instead,
with the idea of ...Nf8, Ng6, Bd7, c6 with a playable game. The text leaves
the center for no good reason.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4
comment:
This is the right plan, just played
too early. Better would've been to prepare this move with Nd3, and possibly
even Kh2, g3, f4 so that way white can recapture f4 with a pawn and therefore
deprive the nice e5 square for black's pieces. As the game goes, white gets a
hole on e5. Squares that cannot be covered by pawns are called holes.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3
comment:
Alert play. It was critical for white to cover
c5 and e5 as soon as possible, to contest any knight outposts by black.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5
comment:
Another mistake by black. This is rather poor play for an expert.
The battle for e5 ("Fight for the Center") is key, therefore he should've
played ...Nf8! with the idea of Ng6, and the stranglehold control of e5 would
give him a small advantage.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5
comment:
Black makes what should've been
his last mistake. White can now win at least a pawn with 18. Nxe5 Qxe5 19.
Qxf7+ Kh8. If instead black tried 18. ... dxe5, then white has 19. d6! cxd6 20.
Bxf7+ Kh8 21. Bxe8 Qxe8 which leave white ahead with a rook for a bishop. One
of the best ways that I suggest to not miss tactics is to always look at
forcing moves.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6
comment:
This unnecessarily weakens light
squares in Black's camp. The reason strong players avoid weakening their
squares if possible is to deny good outposts/lines for the opponent's pieces.
This is precisely what White correctly does in this game, and that is to play
on the light squares. Much better for black would be 19. ... g6! 20. Qe2 Bd7,
which would leave black with a slight advantage. Notice White can't play 20.
Qxh6?? because 20. ... Bg7 21. Qh4 Nf3+ wins White's queen.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6
comment:
Not very good, but postion has deteriated to
the point it's hard to suggest a good move. Black needed to complete
development with 23. ... Bd7 24. Bxd7 Qxd7, and reroute his Knight to e5 and
hope that that counterbalances his holes on e6 and f5. Notice that none of
this would be a problem if he would've played ...g6 earlier.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6 24. c3 Ba7 25. Bc2 Qe8 26. N1f2 Bd7 27. b3
comment: Why not Nf4? if black replies ...Bb5, c4 is an effective rejoinder.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6 24. c3 Ba7 25. Bc2 Qe8 26. N1f2 Bd7 27. b3 Nf7 28. Ng4 Ne5 29. Nf4 Nxg4 30. hxg4 Qe5 31. Ne6
comment:
A good, practical decision, as
bishops of opposites may give chances to draw. With proper play though, black
should still win.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6 24. c3 Ba7 25. Bc2 Qe8 26. N1f2 Bd7 27. b3 Nf7 28. Ng4 Ne5 29. Nf4 Nxg4 30. hxg4 Qe5 31. Ne6 Bxe6 32. dxe6 Qxe6 33. Bd3 Kh8
comment:
Black has been playing this
game entirely too passively. ...Qe5! is much stronger. That move blockades
white's e-pawn (hence hemming white's bishop in), threatens pawns on a5, c3,
and in addition threatens dark-square penetration to white's king-side with ...
Qg3 or ...Qg5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6 24. c3 Ba7 25. Bc2 Qe8 26. N1f2 Bd7 27. b3 Nf7 28. Ng4 Ne5 29. Nf4 Nxg4 30. hxg4 Qe5 31. Ne6 Bxe6 32. dxe6 Qxe6 33. Bd3 Kh8 34. Qf3 Rae8 35. e5
comment: A nice clearance sacrifice. After this move, a draw is the most likely result.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6 24. c3 Ba7 25. Bc2 Qe8 26. N1f2 Bd7 27. b3 Nf7 28. Ng4 Ne5 29. Nf4 Nxg4 30. hxg4 Qe5 31. Ne6 Bxe6 32. dxe6 Qxe6 33. Bd3 Kh8 34. Qf3 Rae8 35. e5 dxe5 36. Qe4 f5

1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Be7 4. d4 d6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. O-O O-O 7. h3 a6 8. a4 h6 9. a5 Re8 10. d5 Nb8 11. Ne1 Nh7 12. f4 exf4 13. Bxf4 Bf6 14. Qf3 Nd7 15. Nd3 Qe7 16. Rae1 Ne5 17. Bxe5 Bxe5 18. Bb3 Ng5 19. Qh5 f6 20. Ba4 Rf8 21. Nd1 Qf7 22. Qe2 Bd4+ 23. Kh1 Qg6 24. c3 Ba7 25. Bc2 Qe8 26. N1f2 Bd7 27. b3 Nf7 28. Ng4 Ne5 29. Nf4 Nxg4 30. hxg4 Qe5 31. Ne6 Bxe6 32. dxe6 Qxe6 33. Bd3 Kh8 34. Qf3 Rae8 35. e5 dxe5 36. Qe4 f5 37. gxf5 Qf6 38. Rf3 Rd8 39. Ref1 c6 40. Rg3 Qf7 41. Rff3 Rd6 42. Rg6 Rf6 43. Qg4 e4 44. Bc4 Qxg6 45. fxg6 exf3 46. gxf3 Rxf3 47. Qd7 Rg3 48. Qxb7 Rg1+ 49. Kh2 Rf2+ 50. Kh3 Rf3+
comment:
You did play aggressively and
with energy, which is good. Try to look at forcing moves, so that you have a
smaller chance of missing a combination. Also, try to minimize making "holes"
in your position, especially in the center of the board. If your opponent has
holes, try to occupy them and use them as springboards for your attack. Don't
worry about ratings too much, as this often can be a distractor from playing
good chess. Try instead to improve your game. Your rating will increase
naturally as your understanding of chess grows.
